candidates.title: Move xtrace-example to x11rb-protocol
candidates.body:
This commit makes the xtrace-example depend on x11rb-protocol instead of
x11rb. To make this possible, some more stuff is moved from x11rb to
x11rb-protocol:

* The all-extensions feature now also exists in x11rb-protocol
* x11_utils::BigRequests and the parse_request_header() function are
  moved over and re-exports are left behind to avoid an API break

Signed-off-by: Uli Schlachter <psychon@znc.in>

candidates.title: Derive `serde` traits for protocol objects
candidates.body: It's generally recommended that objects derive `serde` traits. This PR adds the optional `serde` feature, which derives `serde::Serialize` and `serde::Deserialize` for all protocol objects that don't contain raw FDs.

candidates.title: Set up x11rb-protocol to be no_std
candidates.body:
This pull request adds a new feature to x11rb-protocol, "std", which is enabled by default. With this feature disabled, the crate is able to be used on `no_std` platforms. Note that several features, including display parsing, resource management, and extensions using file descriptors are locked behind this feature.

~~While I was setting up the extensions to be locked behind `no_std`, I also realized that, since FD passing is a well-defined operation only on Unix targets, having these extensions on non-Unix targets would likely lead to errors or undefined behavior. So I also locked these extensions behind the `cfg(unix)` directive.~~ On second thought, I'll leave the option open.

candidates.title: Move XRM database to x11rb-protocol
candidates.body:
This commit moves the code in x11rb::resource_manager to x11rb-protocol.
The only thing requiring I/O in this module is loading the resource
management database. The necessary X11 requests are abstracted out so
that any caller can do so. The file I/O should be quick and is left
as-is.

A new x11rb::resource_manager module is added that provides convenience
functions to load the resource management database from a given &impl
Connection. These functions "close the gap" that is created by the move
to x11rb-protocol and provide exactly the same behaviour as we had
before.

Signed-off-by: Uli Schlachter <psychon@znc.in>

-----

I am not a 100% sure that this code belongs in x11rb-protocol, but we already had it in x11rb, so... yeah. Moving it to a new crate would only complicate things for little gain. This code is already feature-gated, so the result would be (roughly) equivalent.

candidates.title: Add connection benchmarking to x11rb-protocol
candidates.body:
This pull request adds basic benchmarking for the `Connection` type, using the `criterion` crate. Currently, there are two categories of benchmarks here:

- Testing the `enqueue_packet` function, with requests, replies and errors, at varying levels of inner queue capacity.
- Testing the mechanisms for sending requests and receiving replies, by fake-sending a request, enqueuing an appropriate reply in the connection, and then polling for the reply. This also operates with the queues at varying capacity.

Follow-up questions:

- I tried to create loads here that accurately reflect the X11 display's work case: either being empty, or being flooded with requests/replies. Is there a way to make these cases more accurate to real-life X11 cases?
- Are there any other facets of the `Connection` we should consider in these benchmarks?

candidates.title: Update my email address
candidates.body: My previous email address is _deprecated_, this is the new public address that I am also using as commit author.

candidates.title: Add @notgull to the authors list
candidates.body:
Hi @notgull 

You've been working quite a bit on x11rb and, well, yeah... uhm, do you want to be a collaborator on this repo? I just sent you an invite. If you accept the invite, you should be able to review this PR (and leave an approving review) and mergify should then automatically merge this PR (and mergify will automatically delete the branch from which I am creating this PR). I like mergify. And I like reviews. :-)

I copied your `authors`-entry from breadx.

candidates.title: Split out a x11rb-protocol crate
candidates.body:
This commit splits the code into two crates:

"x11rb-protocol" contains the protocol definitions and allows parsing
and serialising things. It does not do any actual I/O.

"x11rb" uses x11rb-protocol and implements an X11 client based on this.

I tried to do as few changes as possible here. Code moves around, but
the structure of the code is not supposed to change.

There is one place where this did not work out:

Previously, e.g. CreateWindowRequest had an associated function send().
This function send the request that it is called on via a given X11
connection. Since this does I/O, this functionality does not belong into
the x11rb-protocol crate. Since it is an associated function, it cannot
easily be provided by x11rb.

For now, I worked around this problem by turning send() into a "free"
function. The resulting name collision was dealt by renaming it to e.g.
send_create_window().

The result of all this is a huge commit. This is still a mess and things
should be cleaned up further in the future, but I didn't want to make
this commit even larger. This is the first version that I managed to get
to compile.

Signed-off-by: Uli Schlachter <psychon@znc.in>

----

CC @notgull

@eduardosm Did you get the mails? Do you have some suggestions/doubts or is this change okay/sensible?

candidates.title: Restrict xtrace-example to older futures version
candidates.body:
A week ago, futures 0.3.18 was released and apparently this does not
work with Rust 1.41.0:
```
   Compiling xtrace-example v0.0.0 (/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/xtrace-example)
     Running `rustc --edition=2018 --crate-name xtrace_example xtrace-example/src/main.rs --error-format=json --json=diagnostic-rendered-ansi --emit=dep-info,link -C debuginfo=2 --test -C metadata=516abdc358c39888 -C extra-filename=-516abdc358c39888 --out-dir /home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/deps -C incremental=/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/incremental -L dependency=/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/deps --extern futures_io=/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/deps/libfutures_io-3756b09c8a44e206.rlib --extern futures_util=/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/deps/libfutures_util-411815ec4958698e.rlib --extern smol=/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/deps/libsmol-b079add982015d84.rlib --extern x11rb=/home/runner/work/x11rb/x11rb/target/debug/deps/libx11rb-768ac55e45ccd24c.rlib`
error[E0658]: procedural macros cannot be expanded to statements
  --> xtrace-example/src/main.rs:90:5
   |
90 |     futures_util::try_join!(future1, future2)?;
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   |
   = note: for more information, see https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/54727
   = note: this error originates in a macro outside of the current crate (in Nightly builds, run with -Z external-macro-backtrace for more info)
```
See https://github.com/psychon/x11rb/runs/4375081831

Signed-off-by: Uli Schlachter <psychon@znc.in>

repo.name: x11rb
repo.description: X11 bindings for the rust programming language, similar to xcb being the X11 C bindings
